Good features without sacrificing simplicity. Timing modes are: * Analog (basic countdown, which can go negative) * Sudden death (like analog, but clocks are locked after a timeout) * Simple delay (US style) * Bronstein delay * Fischer * Canadian * Byo-yomi * Scrabble (like analog, but displays a point penalty that increments for each minute spent past expired time). Players can be given different starting times, but they must have the same increment/delay settings. Most apps these days don't use the context menu, but that's where you change some visual aspects (digital/analog display, move counters on/off), turn sounds on/off, and see some basic statistics for the current game. I would love to see an hourglass timing mode (your time is out if at any point you've used X minutes more than your opponent).

Along with everything this great app has to offer there is one thing that reduces the experience for me, thus the four stars. The issue is that both the menu button and the restart button (which curiously do the same thing - they reset players' times) do reset the times without confirmation. This leads to accidental time reset in blitz when players push all over the phone. My advice is to reset times only after confirmation and to remove time reset function from the menu button.

I've tried others, and this one is the best. It shows both player's time in the same direction (so no player is seeing his/her time upside down). Furthermore, it's sensitive; a single tick on it would do.

Unlike the others this one had all the delay options (simple, bronstein, Fischer), a professional look (for the simple interface... The others are ehhh...), and complete information on the clock face (# of moves and delay time remaining). Can also write your own names in for player 1 and player 2.  It does have small ads, but apparently you can ax them for a buck.  Next best was Chess Cloid... in case this doesn't work for you.
